Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: The school reports that the child was caught bullying a classmate, and the parent needs to respond
Situation2: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Story: I stared at my phone, heart pounding. The school had just called—my son was caught bullying a classmate. They wanted me to come in, talk to the principal, and help my child understand the seriousness of his actions. I felt a wave of guilt and responsibility; I needed to be there for him, to guide him, to show him right from wrong. But as I hung up, I heard my boyfriend’s voice from the living room, shaky and low. He’d just gotten terrible feedback at work, and I could see the defeat in his eyes. He needed me too—someone to listen, to reassure him, to remind him of his worth. I felt torn in two, pulled by the urgent needs of my child and my partner. Both expected my full attention, my comfort, my presence. My chest tightened as I tried to figure out how to be the parent my son needed and the girlfriend my partner deserved, all at the same time.
